elements.description:
The gain on the sound-component. Note that gain is in linear scale,
between 0 and 1.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
  local gain = go.get("#sound", "gain")
  go.set("#sound", "gain", gain * 1.5)
end
elements.name: gain

elements.description:
The pan on the sound-component. The valid range is from -1.0 to 1.0,
representing -45 degrees left, to +45 degrees right.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
  local pan = go.get("#sound", "pan")
  go.set("#sound", "pan", pan * -1)
end
elements.name: pan

elements.description:
The speed on the sound-component where 1.0 is normal speed, 0.5 is half
speed and 2.0 is double speed.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
  local speed = go.get("#sound", "speed")
  go.set("#sound", "speed", speed * 0.5)
end
elements.name: speed

elements.description: The sound data used when playing the sound. The type of the property is hash.
elements.examples:
How to change the sound: 
function init(self)
  -- load a wav file bundled as a custom resource
  local wav = sys.load_resource("foo.wav")
  -- get resource path to the sound component
  local resource_path = go.get("#sound", "sound")
  -- update the resource with the loaded wav file
  resource.set_sound(resource_path, wav)
  -- play the updated sound
  sound.play("#sound")
end
elements.name: sound

elements.description:
Checks if background music is playing, e.g. from iTunes. On non mobile platforms, this function always return false. On Android you can only get a correct reading of this state if your game is not playing any sounds itself. This is a limitation in the Android SDK. If your game is playing any sounds, even with a gain of zero, this function will return false. The best time to call this function is:
  • In the init function of your main collection script before any sounds are triggered
  • In a window listener callback when the window.WINDOW_EVENT_FOCUS_GAINED event is received
Both those times will give you a correct reading of the state even when your application is swapped out and in while playing sounds and it works equally well on Android and iOS.
elements.brief: check if background music is playing
elements.examples:
If music is playing, mute "master": 
if sound.is_music_playing() then
    -- mute "master"
    sound.set_group_gain("master", 0)
end
elements.name: sound.is_music_playing

elements.description: Get RMS (Root Mean Square) value from mixer group. This value is the square root of the mean (average) value of the squared function of the instantaneous values. For instance: for a sinewave signal with a peak gain of -1.94 dB (0.8 linear), the RMS is 0.8 × 1/sqrt(2) which is about 0.566. Note the returned value might be an approximation and in particular the effective window might be larger than specified.
elements.brief: get RMS value from mixer group
elements.examples:
Get the RMS from the "master" group where a mono -1.94 dB sinewave is playing: 
local rms = sound.get_rms("master", 0.1) -- throw away right channel.
print(rms) --> 0.56555819511414
elements.name: sound.get_rms

elements.description: Get peak value from mixer group. Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20. Also note that the returned value might be an approximation and in particular the effective window might be larger than specified.
elements.brief: get peak gain value from mixer group
elements.examples:
Get the peak gain from the "master" group and convert to dB for displaying: 
local left_p, right_p = sound.get_peak("master", 0.1)
left_p_db = 20 * log(left_p)
right_p_db = 20 * log(right_p)
elements.name: sound.get_peak

elements.description: Set mixer group gain Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20.
elements.examples:
Set mixer group gain on the "soundfx" group to -4 dB: 
local gain_db = -4
local gain = 10^gain_db/20 -- 0.63095734448019
sound.set_group_gain("soundfx", gain)
elements.name: sound.set_group_gain

elements.description: Get mixer group gain Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20.
elements.examples:
Get the mixer group gain for the "soundfx" and convert to dB: 
local gain = sound.get_group_gain("soundfx")
local gain_db = 20 * log(gain)
elements.name: sound.get_group_gain

elements.description: Get a table of all mixer group names (hashes).
elements.examples:
Get the mixer groups, set all gains to 0 except for "master" and "soundfx" where gain is set to 1: 
local groups = sound.get_groups()
for _,group in ipairs(groups) do
    if group == hash("master") or group == hash("soundfx") then
        sound.set_group_gain(group, 1)
    else
        sound.set_group_gain(group, 0)
    end
end
elements.name: sound.get_groups

elements.description: Get a mixer group name as a string. This function is to be used for debugging and development tooling only. The function does a reverse hash lookup, which does not return a proper string value when the game is built in release mode.
elements.examples:
Get the mixer group string names so we can show them as labels on a dev mixer overlay: 
local groups = sound.get_groups()
for _,group in ipairs(groups) do
    local name = sound.get_group_name(group)
    msg.post("/mixer_overlay#gui", "set_mixer_label", { group = group, label = name})
end
elements.name: sound.get_group_name

elements.description: Checks if a phone call is active. If there is an active phone call all other sounds will be muted until the phone call is finished. On non mobile platforms, this function always return false.

returnvalues.doc: true if there is an active phone call, false otherwise.
returnvalues.name: call_active

elements.brief: check if a phone call is active
elements.examples:
Test if a phone call is on-going: 
if sound.is_phone_call_active() then
    -- do something sensible.
end
elements.name: sound.is_phone_call_active

elements.description: Make the sound component play its sound. Multiple voices are supported. The limit is set to 32 voices per sound component. Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20. A sound will continue to play even if the game object the sound component belonged to is deleted. You can call sound.stop() to stop the sound.

parameters.doc:
optional table with properties:
delay
number delay in seconds before the sound starts playing, default is 0.
gain
number sound gain between 0 and 1, default is 1. The final gain of the sound will be a combination of this gain, the group gain and the master gain.
pan
number sound pan between -1 and 1, default is 0. The final pan of the sound will be an addition of this pan and the sound pan.
speed
number sound speed where 1.0 is normal speed, 0.5 is half speed and 2.0 is double speed. The final speed of the sound will be a multiplication of this speed and the sound speed.
parameters.name: [play_properties]

parameters.doc:
function to call when the sound has finished playing.
self
object The current object.
message_id
hash The name of the completion message, "sound_done".
message
table Information about the completion:
  • number play_id - the sequential play identifier that was given by the sound.play function.
sender
url The invoker of the callback: the sound component.
parameters.name: [complete_function]

returnvalues.doc: The identifier for the sound voice
returnvalues.name: id

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will make the component play its sound after 1 second: 
sound.play("#sound", { delay = 1, gain = 0.5, pan = -1.0 } )
Using the callback argument, you can chain several sounds together: 
local function sound_done(self, message_id, message, sender)
  -- play 'boom' sound fx when the countdown has completed
  if message_id == hash("sound_done") and message.play_id == self.countdown_id then
    sound.play("#boom", nil, sound_done)
  end
end

function init(self)
  self.countdown_id = sound.play("#countdown", nil, sound_done)
end
elements.name: sound.play

elements.description: Stop playing all active voices
elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will make the component stop all playing voices: 
sound.stop("#sound")
elements.name: sound.stop

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will make the component pause all playing voices:

elements.description: Set gain on all active playing voices of a sound. Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20.

parameters.doc: the sound to set the gain of
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: sound gain between 0 and 1. The final gain of the sound will be a combination of this gain, the group gain and the master gain.
parameters.name: [gain]

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will set the gain to 0.5

elements.description:
Set panning on all active playing voices of a sound.
The valid range is from -1.0 to 1.0, representing -45 degrees left, to +45 degrees right.

parameters.doc: the sound to set the panning value to
parameters.name: url

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will set the gain to 0.5

elements.name: sound.set_pan

elements.description: Post this message to a sound-component to make it play its sound. Multiple voices is supported. The limit is set to 32 voices per sound component. Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20. A sound will continue to play even if the game object the sound component belonged to is deleted. You can send a stop_sound to stop the sound.

parameters.doc: delay in seconds before the sound starts playing, default is 0.
parameters.name: [delay]

parameters.doc: sound gain between 0 and 1, default is 1.
parameters.name: [gain]

parameters.doc: the identifier of the sound, can be used to distinguish between consecutive plays from the same component.
parameters.name: [play_id]

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will make the component play its sound after 1 second: 
msg.post("#sound", "play_sound", {delay = 1, gain = 0.5})
elements.name: play_sound

elements.description: Post this message to a sound-component to make it stop playing all active voices
elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will make the component stop all playing voices: 
msg.post("#sound", "stop_sound")
elements.name: stop_sound

elements.description: Post this message to a sound-component to set gain on all active playing voices. Note that gain is in linear scale, between 0 and 1. To get the dB value from the gain, use the formula 20 * log(gain). Inversely, to find the linear value from a dB value, use the formula 10db/20.

parameters.doc: sound gain between 0 and 1, default is 1.
parameters.name: [gain]

elements.examples:
Assuming the script belongs to an instance with a sound-component with id "sound", this will set the gain to 0.5 
msg.post("#sound", "set_gain", {gain = 0.5})
elements.name: set_gain

elements.description: This message is sent back to the sender of a play_sound message, if the sound could be played to completion.

parameters.doc: id number supplied when the message was posted.
parameters.name: [play_id]

elements.brief: reports when a sound has finished playing
elements.name: sound_done
